dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sold sign is posted in front of a house. SHOT OF SIGN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is empty except for Bekins boxes which are packed. They are all over the rooms. The CAMERA SLOWLY MOVES IN AND AROUND the boxes until we REACH the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bed is the only piece of furniture left. The CAM- ERA STOPS. In front of the bed is a small black-and- white television. In bed are DAVID and NANCY HOWARD. Nancy is rolled over on her side. David is lying on his back with his eyes wide open.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy? Nancy?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sleeping?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Maybe we shouldn't move.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Oh God. What's the matter now?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nothing. It's just time to ask these questions.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. We've sold our house and bought another one. These questions should have been asked before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, fine. I can't talk to you. Good night. David pretends like he's actually going to go to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (in a monotone; obvi- ously she's had to say this many times before) Stop it. You're nervous about tomorrow. You'll get your promotion, don't worry. We'll move into our new house and we'll be happy, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Boy, you should hear yourself. The excitement in your voice just fills the room.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Look, I'm tired. Stop questioning. We made a wise decision. Let's try and feel good about it, alright?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fine.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good night. Nancy tries to go back to sleep. David just lies there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) But why that house?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think it's too close to here.  It's going to feel like the same place. Maybe we really didn't think about this long enough.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We thought about it forever. We wanted more space. That house has more space.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, but the point of a house is not just space. You can rent space. Maybe we should've moved into a completely different neighborhood, a step up or something. Maybe we should've gotten a house with a tennis court.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why? We don't play tennis.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sure we don't play tennis. We don't have a court. When you have a court, you learn.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, possibly some day, we'll have a court and then we can learn.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let me ask you one more question? Why did we let Bekins do all of our packing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Isn't that a waste of money? We could've packed ourselves. Maybe we were too irresponsible.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't believe you. One minute you want a tennis court, the next minute you're worried about Bekins  packing a box? My God. Sometimes I wish we really were irresponsible.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nothing. Look, get some sleep, okay? You'll feel better.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don't assume how I'm feeling. What do you mean "nothing"? If you're saying we should be more irresponsible, I imagine you mean we're too responsible? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, sometimes I think that we are too controlled, yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Well, tell me something? How do you go out and buy a four-hundred-thousand- dollar house and let a moving company pack everything and get maids and servants and live the good life and not be controlled?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I'm talking about. David gets up. He takes his pillow with him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm going to sleep in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Don't do that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why not? I'm responsible. I  should be guarding the car.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're insane.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (yelling from the kitchen) You're right. I am insane. I am insane and I'm responsible. A very, very good combination. We STAY in the bedroom with Nancy. She lies there. Her eyes are open. She's staring straight ahead. She looks sad. After a moment, David reappears at the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am not an animal.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I am not an animal. I will not sleep in the garage.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Just come to bed. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (sitting down on the bed) I apologize, okay? But don't call me names.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What names?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know what names. Calling me responsible is saying what? That I'm closed up. I'm old. I'm stodgy. That's not fair. I don't like the way things are any more than anybody else does but what am I supposed to do? I'm trying. What about you? You're as responsible as I am. Personnel Director for a department store is  not the most irresponsible job in the world. Go hire anyone you want. Think you'd be fired fast if you did that? How much freedom do you have? We're all in the same boat. We're trying to make something of ourselves and it's hard. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're very upset. I'm sorry I used that word.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I'm glad you used that word. It's honest but things are going to get better. They're going to change.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You always say that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, but this time it's different. After tomorrow I'm no longer an employee, I'm a Vice President. I'll be my own boss. I'll have a piece of the company. You see what I mean? I can be more irresponsible because I'll be in a position of responsibility. That makes sense, doesn't it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't know. I guess it does. Good night.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, go to sleep. Nancy and David both lie down, each facing the oppo- site direction. After a few seconds...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) It does make sense and things will work out, don't you think so?  No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nancy? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Asleep already? No answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Maybe men are supposed to fall asleep last. It could be a protective thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is brushing his teeth. He stops for a minute and looks in the mirror. He starts talking, pretend- ing the face he's seeing is the one of his boss.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What can I say? I'd be a liar if I tell you I'm surprised. I do feel it's deserved but yes, I still am flattered... That's very nice. Thank you... Oh, stop, please. I've never been good at taking too many compliments at once... Well, I feel the same way about you. Nancy walks in during this. She watches him for a bit.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (interrupting him) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (caught off guard) Why? Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you talking to?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to anybody. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm leaving now. Mr. Taft will be there in twenty minutes. Please be on time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wait a second. I can't do this today. I can't choose tiles. This is my big day. Please? You do it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We're trying to do this together. I think it's important.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm very nervous and it's your kitchen anyway. You'll make the right choice.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're in the kitchen more than I am.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But I'm not thinking about anything when I'm in the kitchen. I don't really care.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We said we would make these decisions together.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Come on. It's just today.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (exasperated, turn- ing around and leaving) Fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please don't be mad.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm not mad. After a moment, she comes back in.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Good luck. You'll get it. You deserve it. Nancy exits.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you. And I trust any decision you make. You have great taste. There's no answer.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing; call- ing after her) Really, you have great taste. (turns back around to the mirror) I'm sorry. That was my wife... Yes, she has wonderful taste. She's going to choose the whole tile thing herself. Originally, we were going to do it together but it's nice to be able to trust someone, don't you think?... Well, that's very nice. I trust you, too. Hey!... When our house is finished maybe you'd like to come over and play tennis... No, but we might put one in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see David pulling into the garage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is walking down the corridor towards his office. He's saying "Hello"'s to various people. He comes to his own office. There we see his secretary, SUSAN, on the telephone. Obviously, she's making a personal call and she hangs up abnormally fast as soon as she sees David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Morning.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Good morning. Your meeting is in forty-five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh my God. What time is it now?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Ten-thirty.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. (thinking aloud) Ten-thirty, eleven, eleven-fifteen okay. Susan, don't let any calls in. I don't want to be bothered. I don't want to do any business. I just want to prepare. David walks into his office. After a beat, he sticks his head out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh yes. Get me Valley Mercedes, will you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We FOLLOW Nancy as she's walking through the department store. She comes to her office. Her office is on the third floor in the corner with the other business offi-  ces. Her friend, PATTY, who works with her, is in the office next door. All offices are separated by glass partitions. Nancy comes in and sits down. Patty sees her and enters.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Hi. Nancy looks up from her desk.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Is it beautiful?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: The kitchen. What does it look like?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (half-heartedly) I chose an orange tile.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Orange?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: A burnt orange.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Sounds pretty.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Patty, close the door. Patty closes the door and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm going to hate this house.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When the contractor left this morning, I was all alone there and I sat in the middle of the living room and I got so sad. I got this preview of the next ten years, I just started shaking. Patty just stares at her. She knows that Nancy is serious.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) I'm so unhappy. I don't like anything anymore. I don't like my job. I don't like my life. I don't like anything. I feel dead.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nothing's changing. I'm not growing. David's not growing. We've just stopped. Life is passing us by.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Listen, you've had a tough week. With the moving and everything you're very tired. When you get tired you feel bad. Things seem worse.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm not that tired. Do you know I've been hiring girls who are nineteen years old, who've already had more experience out of life than I have?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You don't know that. You can't tell what a person has experienced just by interviewing them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's forget it. I really haven't thought this through enough. I don't want to discuss it now. Let's get to work.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: No. I'm sorry. I didn't mean to say the wrong thing. Have you talked this over with David?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Of course not. That's the problem. I can't talk anything over with him. It's hopeless.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Are you thinking of splitting up?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, that's not my first choice but what's the alternative? And I'm not blaming David. I know he genuinely believes that being made Vice President is going to change things. But he genuinely believed that every promotion would change things. It never does. Maybe for a few days, but that's it. Then things are always the same.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Well, this is vice president. Maybe this time it will change.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: And what if it won't?

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: Then it won't. Then you get divorced, I don't know. Whatever you have to do.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, God. Maybe it will.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: It will or it won't.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay. I'm starting to feel sick to my stomach. Thanks for talking to me. Let's just say maybe it will.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (standing up) Good. Because if it won't, it won't anyway so what can you do?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We said we'd stop on "will."

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: We did. We've stopped. It will. Patty hesitantly backs out of Nancy's office.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: (continuing) It will. It will work out. Nancy stares straight ahead. She looks very depressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is writing at his desk talking on the telephone. He's writing down figures.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, then tax, license, out-the- door, everything included, what are we talking about?... Thirty- six thousand, five hundred and twelve. Jesus! For a car... No I know, a Mercedes. It's still a car... Well, I don't care. To me, if it has wheels, it's a car. But that's not the point. Now, that's everything, right? That's it? You don't have to pay that  money and then be told that there are options? No extras, everything included... Come on! - For thirty- seven thousand, leather is extra? What kind of seats are in there?... What is Mercedes Leather?... So, why don't you just say vinyl?... Okay, thick vinyl, but it's still vinyl... Okay, these kind of semantic arguments are silly. The BUZZER RINGS.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Just a moment. (presses the intercom) Yes?

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: It's eleven ten.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you. Susan, I have another one of these Mercedes guys on the phone, he won't hang up. Would you do something with him please? David hangs up. He stands and walks over to a small mirror. He straightens his tie, fixes his jacket and carries on one more little conversation with himself as the boss.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) What can I say? I guess, thank you... Oh, no. I can't take your office. This is too nice. Where would you sit?... Well, you are a very generous man. He smiles and exits his office.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: (still on the phone)  No! We will call you back. (she hangs up) What a strange job to be arrogant in.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: SUSAN
dialogues.text: Good luck. Don't worry, you've got it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thanks, Susan. We FOLLOW David as he rounds the corners of this large building on the way to Paul Dunn's office. With each step he is ready to accept this new responsibility. He stops at his boss's secretary, MARGARET, a woman in her older forties, a true executive type.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Well, you look very nice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you and so do you, Margaret.

dialogues.speaker: MARGARET
dialogues.text: Go on in.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thanks. David enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PAUL DUNN is one of the heads of the advertising agency. He certainly holds the top position on the West Coast. His office is large. It smells of success. Obviously this is a man who has made a great deal of money and spen it where people can see it. As David enters, he sees Paul sitting behind his desk and a baldheaded gentleman, BRAD TOOLEY, seated on the couch. Brad Tooley is in his early forties, very well-dressed in the upper Eastern advertising establishment manner. As David comes in,  Brad and Paul both get up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (his hand out- stretched) Hello, David. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm fine. I'm excited.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, I'd like you to meet Brad Tooley.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Brad, it's a pleasure. David and Brad shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Brad has recently joined the agency in New York. He was one of the best men at Doyle, Dane and Bernbach. We were lucky to get him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, that's exciting. They all sit down again. David doesn't know quite what to make of the fact that Brad is in this meeting. He just assumes this is part of the ceremony of being made vice president.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, I don't have to tell you what I think of you. You know I feel you're one of the most creative people in this company. I was telling Brad earlier the accounts you've been responsible for.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: Very impressive. The Knudsen Orange Juice campaign was one of the best I've ever seen. Ever.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (he smiles; he's in his glory) Well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Brad has joined this company for a very special reason. David, we're going to get Ford. David, now thinking of himself as the vice president, realizes that Ford is an account of such proportion, that the profit participation could be enormous. His eyes widen.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! That's wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, it finally puts us at the top of the heap.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm stunned. When did this happen?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Just in the last few days. You're really the first to know out here. We didn't want to say anything until it was final.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's wonderful. Just wonderful. God, what a week. What a week for all of us.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: It certainly is. Now, David...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Paul, you don't have to say anything. As the new vice president, I know what this means to the company. I'm here twenty-four  hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, you're too valuable to become vice president. I'd like you to move to New York and work under Brad. You two are going to be in charge of Ford. You're going to have to hurry, though. You start in three weeks. David is not quite sure what he's just heard. He thinks maybe he's heard a compliment. He's heard a name of a city, a car, some weeks, but he hasn't put it together. He needs to hear it again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wait a second. You gave me too much information. I'm valuable and I'm vice president?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No, David. I've hired Paul Shubano as vice president.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: He's giving you quite a compliment, David. I asked him for the best man he had and he didn't hesitate for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He didn't? Well, I don't want to move to New York.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I want to be the vice president. I want to be a stockholder in this company. It was promised to me. I don't mind working on Ford. Don't get me wrong. I think it would be a joy to work on but I'll work on it as vice president. I've  been here eight years, Paul. I don't want to be transferred to just another account.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This is not "just another" account, David.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: It's Ford.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Brad, I know it's Ford. I've owned Fords, okay? Now, Paul, I feel it's only fair to keep your promise.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn't promise you anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. What about these lunches that we've been having for the last four years? I believe we talked about grooming me for vice president. Phil Shubano's been here only three years. Why?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, first of all, quite frankly, he's not as clever as you. He's more of an executive type.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, great. I think that's wonderful. So, by being extra clever, I get thrown out of the town that I live in, with no promotion, no nothing, and just shifted to another account. He, on the other hand, because of his low intelligence and short time with the company stays here, gets a large amount of stock and becomes vice president. Well, that makes sense!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You keep referring to this as "another account." It's not. It's Ford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you stop saying that? You sound like Dinah Shore. Now, damn it, look, this isn't fair. (stops for a minute; begins to laugh) Paul, if I'm working myself up and this is a joke, I'll kill you. Are they going to burst in here and say, "Surprise!"? Goddamnit. You almost had me fooled!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No one's bursting in here, David. I'm offering you something very big.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No one's bursting in here?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No? Oh God. But, wait a minute, I'm vice president, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stop saying no! Just a minute. I can't go to New York. This is my home. My wife and I live here. I just bought a four-hundred thousand dollar house. I'm picking tile out at this very moment. What am I going to do? Burn it down?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Don't worry about that, please? You won't lose a penny on the house.  We'll take care of it. I think Ford is more important than a single family dwelling, anyway. We'll get you more than you paid for it. The important thing is that you and Brad get along.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Me and Brad get along? Are you crazy? I've worked here eight years, for what? For me and Brad to get along? I was born in this city. All my friends are here. I like it. We're joking, aren't we? This is a joke.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: What do you mean, a joke?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean, a joke?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn't say a joke.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm going to New York City?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I'd like you there in three weeks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, you would?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: This can be a stepping stone to something bigger, David.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What's bigger than being vice president? That's all I want. Maybe I'm wrong, but I think I've already stepped on every stone we have here, haven't I?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: Well, someday you might be vice president.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday? What do you mean? It's today. I've got it!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: You don't have it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who has it?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, I can't say this again. Phil Shubano.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, obviously, I'm blocking this man's name, aren't I?

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: David, I don't know all of your work, but I do know you've got to be the best here or you wouldn't be working with me on this account.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Brad, shut up! Don't talk! This is my day. Paul, look what you're doing. I've been with this company a very, very long time. I'm one of the oldest employees on this coast aren't I? Now, I must get what I deserve. I will be made vice president and I will get the stock and I will participate in the ownership of the company and that's that.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: My God, I thought you'd be thrilled.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You thought I'd be thrilled? I can't believe it. Why the hell don't you go to New York? If it's so thrilling, come on, I'll take you to the airport. I'll put you on a plane right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't talk to me like that. I came from New York.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's right and you don't want to go back because as soon as you land at the airport, people steal everything you've got.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I resent that. That's a clichВ®. New York's the greatest city there is.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sit down. Just sit down and shut up.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, that's enough.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. I haven't even started yet. Now listen, let's say a giant mistake was made. Pretend none of this was ever said. I'm the vice president. Everything will be fine. I'll stay here. I'11 work on Ford. I'll move into my new house. You and Brad can come over for drinks. And now, let's bring out Allen Funt and everybody will yell, "Surprise," right? I'm vice president, right?

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: David, the position is filled.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, then you can go fuck yourself!

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: (gets up) Paul, I can't work with this man.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can't either. David, you're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fired! How dare you? I can't believe this! You want to know something? I was nervous about coming in here today. I said to my friends, "Maybe I won't get this." You know what everyone of them said? "Stop it. You're being stupid. You're the best man. There's no one else. You're the best man." And what does the best man do? He stands next to the groom and watches the groom become vice president!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I can see you're upset. I'll forget what you said earlier. I don't think you want to jeopardize eight years with this company.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fuck you!

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: That's it. Get out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I wasted my youth for you and for what? What do you mean jeopardize eight years? What eight years? All I did was live for the future. Why didn't you tell me a long time ago that I was too clever? You should have told me five years ago, then I could've gone somewhere else.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: I didn't know it five years ago.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don't say anything else. I'll kill you.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (presses a buzzer) Get me security, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, I can't believe it. Security. Okay, listen to me. I want my eight years back! Give me my life back! I want my eight years back! Give them to me! Paul stares at him. Brad gets up.

dialogues.speaker: BRAD
dialogues.text: I'm going back to the hotel. David, you're making a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You don't even know me, you baldheaded fart! Brad stares at him and then walks out. He turns back to Paul.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I can't believe that I almost wasted my entire life here! I've been waiting very, very patiently and I realize now what would've happened. This would've gone on for years and years and years and when I was seventy, I would've gotten a watch. Actually you wouldn't even have given me a watch. You would've told me I was too clever, that I would instinctively know the time. You know something, Paul? I made fun of my friends who dropped out of college and went to "find themselves." I told them they were stupid. I laughed at them. And what did I do? I went with you. Good choice, wasn't it? What did I get for doing that? A transfer. I could've gotten that from a bus. You're a human bus, Jesus Christ! You liar! I don't know where those drop-outs are today, but I've got to find them! I owe them a big apology. 'Cause let me tell you something. They have more integrity on their little tab of acid than you have in your entire body, you  big fucking jerk! A security guard enters.

dialogues.speaker: PAUL
dialogues.text: (stands up) Would you escort Mr. Howard out, please?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: He doesn't have to escort me out. I'm honored to leave. David opens the office door. He begins to yell so everyone can hear him. This is reminiscent of the scene from "Network."

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Before I leave, I think it's very important for everyone in this company to know what went on in here today. I don't know how many lunches you've all had with that man and I don't know what he's said over salad or dessert or whatever he buys you, but you better not believe it! He's a real smoothie! He'll tell you about the stepping stones! That's his favorite expression. He'll tell you about the stepping stones and where they lead. Well, I found out where they lead! To a baldheaded fat man in New York! Get out! Get out now! Smell the roses! Smell anything! Just smell! Smell before it's too late!! The office is applauding wildly. We HOLD on them for a second.

dialogues.speaker: BEVERLY HILLS ROBINSON'S DEPT. STORE
dialogues.text: David's car enters the parking lot at high speed. The car screeches to a halt. He jumps out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks hurriedly towards the elevators oblivious to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is walking towards the personnel office. We've never seen him like this before. He's alive. He's got more than bounce in his step. It's as if he weighs 12 pounds. He's on another planet. He's smiling at every- body. He has the look of a "Re-born." As he enters the personnel department, he sees Nancy in her office. Because Nancy's office is separated from the others by a thin piece of glass, if you speak too loudly everyone can hear. David is not about to lower his voice. He has no concept anymore of volume. He's just too excited. David bursts in.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy! Nancy looks up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: God, you scared me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy, come here. (he pulls her up by her shoulders) Quit. Quit, right now. We're getting out.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Now. Quit.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Quit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now. Come on. I did. Now, you do it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You did? You quit your job?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Surprised, aren't you? You wouldn't have believed me. You would've loved it. No more me. No more waiting. No more responsible David. Jesus, they were leading me down a dead-end street! I've been on the wrong road. I realize what you meant. I've been too responsible. So responsible, God! I've been responsibly blind!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I never would've used the word responsible if I thought you would have taken it so literally. It was just a word. I really didn't mean anything by it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Stop. Don't do this. Don't. I'm giving you the credit. You did mean it and you were right. I don't know where the hell I've been for the last ten years. What happened to me? I lost the feeling of life. Jesus, I was being jacked off. Nancy, they were just jacking me off! David's voice is a bit loud. We can see people look from other offices.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Honey, shh. (whispering) A little lower, please?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (whispering) Okay. They were jacking me off. (his voice starts  to rise again) They were leading me down this road. You know, this road?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What road?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The road to nowhere. You know the road. The Nowhere Road. I was being tugged along with this carrot. "Come here. Come here. Come here." But no one told me it was a fucking cul-de-sac! We've been on the wrong road.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Who was made vice president?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (laughing it off) Oh, Nancy, that's all over now. That's kid's stuff. (in a childlike voice) Vice President. Class Secretary. Cloakroom Monitor. Treasurer. They're all stupid. (regular voice) If you really want to know who it was, it was Phil Shubano.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No! Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We'll never know. The Lord works in mysterious ways, but if there is a God, you know what will happen to Phil? He'll get his profit sharing and he'll buy a boat with it and he'll crash the boat and die.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Stop it. You like Phil. You don't mean that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Of course I like him, the under- qualified son-of-a-bitch. Okay  I was harsh. He'll crash the boat. He'll have a serious injury but he'll recover. But forget about Phil! Forget about the vice presidency! That's the past. Nancy, it's time to do it. We're still young. We can change courses. We can do what we should've done years ago, what our smart friends did. We can get out there. We can get out and see this country. We can find out what it's about. We can touch Indians. We can live in the mountains. We can do anything we want to do. And we're still young enough to really explore. So come on, let's go. We're late. I'll wait here. Go quit. Come on. We're leaving.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can't just quit right now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (looking at her with a lust we haven't seen before) Oh, God, I want to fuck you. Come on. Let's fuck, right here. Nancy is trying, without success, not to call anymore attention to this particular discussion.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (lowered voice) We can do it later. There's a lot of people around now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There's always going to be people around. That was the problem. We lived for them, not for us. It's okay. There are some people you want to fuck in front of and some people you don't. Maybe you don't want to fuck in front of these people, I don't mind. I'll be outside. You quit. I'll wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't quit now, even if I want to. There is no one I can quit to. My boss is not here. We'll talk more about it tonight, please?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, but we're saved. Honey, we're saved. Somebody up there likes us. I don't know who it is, but we're going to find them. We'll find everybody who likes us. We'll start finding people who understand what life is all about. We'll find people who are really searching. We'll find people who are willing to take a chance. Look, I'll just get all excited and get into it all again. You go and finish what you have to do and then I'll see you tonight. David exits. Nancy watches him go. She's expressionless. She doesn't quite know what to make of this. You can sense that part of her thinks that maybe her prayers were answered, maybe this is how the marriage can be saved. You can also sense that part of her isn't sure her husban is sane. Maybe this won't last more than an hour and you can sense the last part of her is still embarrassed that the other employees she works with have heard words like "fuck" and "jacking off." This is a woman of many parts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Nancy are sitting on the floor. They're surrounded by various maps, atlases and cata- logues that show different pieces of property around the United States, property that most people forget even exist. These places look amazing in their little pictures and, in fact, they might be amazing. It's just that almost no one ever gets there to see them for real. The longer Nancy has a chance to see what her husband is saying, the more excited she becomes.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (looking in one of the catalogues)  Look at this. This is the cutest farmhouse I've ever seen. Twenty- four acres near Darien, Connecticut, five bedrooms, eighty thousand dollars? How could that be?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because it's there. It's not here. We're used to this city. You know what our new house would cost, if it were where this farmhouse was? Not four hundred thousand, maybe sixty thousand if we were lucky. Nancy is still looking at pages in the catalogue. She stops at one picture. She is fascinated.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My God. Look at this. A converted lighthouse in Maine, fifty-five thousand, two bedrooms, a living room, a kitchen, a playroom. How do you put this into a lighthouse?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, maybe you go to Maine and find out. Or you don't. You do anything you want. Nancy, look at this... He opens a piece of paper, showing her the arithmetic he has worked on all afternoon.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) This seems to make sense to me. You tell me what you think. The one good thing about spending all this time in Los Angeles was that we got a free ride on this bullshit inflation train. Don't ask me how it happened, but we made a hundred and ninety thousand dollar profit by staying in this house for less than five years. Now, that was money we were never going to see 'cause we were about to put it back into another stupid house. Okay. We pull out of that house,  we lose our fifteen thousand dollars in Escrow, we take the money from this house, we liquidate everything else we have, cars, stocks, bonds, everything... Nancy, we have two hundred thousand dollars!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We do. David shows her the figures. As Nancy looks at the piece of paper, he continues:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) All we need to buy is a motor home and we should get a great one because we might live there for the rest of our lives, or for five years or ten years or whatever.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do you think a motor home costs?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Guess who went motor home shopping? We can get a great one for twenty- five thousand dollars. If there's one thing you can get a deal on it's a motor home. This is the best time in history to drop out. It's a buyer's market!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So that would leave us a hundred and seventy-five thousand dollars. I can't believe it!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes! On that kind of money we could ramble across the country for years! We can paint, we can explore, we can meet amazing people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And if we get to Connecticut and we like one of these farmhouses, we'd have enough money to put a down payment on it, wouldn't we?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes! Then if we get sick of that we could sell it and move on.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'd like to go to Alaska.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Great! Alaska's great! We can do anything we want.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is what we talked about when we were nineteen!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. We talked about finding ourselves but we laughed it off because we had no money. Now we can do it in comfort. We've got our nest egg. This is a dream come true. Nancy has a tear in her eye. David sees it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's wrong? Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We really can do whatever we want to, can't we?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Who's stopping us? Nancy stares. She thinks about that question. She can't come up with an answer. Finally, almost in tears.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nobody's stopping us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PETE HIRSCH is one of David's former associates at the agency. He and his wife are throwing a party for David and Nancy, a final farewell gathering. There are people milling about, talking, general good cheer. David and Nancy are the heroes of the evening. In the corner of the room is a huge cake. The CAMERA MOVES ABOUT, PICKING UP various bits of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PATTY
dialogues.text: You look very happy. You look so good. I'm happy for you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I know you are. She gives Patty a hug. An older, dignified-looking man, JACK MARTIN and his wife, CAROL, approach Nancy. Obvi- ously, he's an executive at Robinson's.

dialogues.speaker: JACK MARTIN
dialogues.text: Well, well.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I didn't know you were going to come.

dialogues.speaker: JACK MARTIN
dialogues.text: (he gives her a paternal hug) One employee we are certainly going to miss.

dialogues.speaker: CAROL
dialogues.text: (to Nancy) I think it sounds wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A group of men are gathered around David. One of David's friends at work, JIM, is speaking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were great. Man, it was great. It was like "Network" and "Take This Job and Shove It," all rolled into one. When you left, we all wanted to go with you. Really. People really had to think for a minute. They were ready to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Did anyone else leave?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No. I mean after a few minutes, people just went back to work but for the moment, it was real exciting.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, when the time's right, if people want to leave, they will.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Of course. I believe that. I got to be honest with you, though. I was thinking about my situation and I don't think I have the guts.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't know that it's guts. It just takes a certain kind of person.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yeah, maybe it has nothing to do with guts. 'Cause I think I have guts. I guess I'm not that kind of person. Let's say that I like expensive things and I guess I need my job to get what I like.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Whatever makes you happy.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Right. I guess expensive things make me happy. These shoes make me happy. Do you like them? He shows David his shoes. They look very expensive.  For a moment, David forgets he will no longer partic-вЂ” ipate in this world.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Beauties. What are they? Bally's?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: A Bally copy. Bally's would be three hundred bucks. These were a hundred and eighty. Can't tell the difference. The sole's just as thick. Look, feel the sole.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (starts to touch the bottom of his shoe and then stops) No, I don't know where you've been, Jim. I don't want to touch your shoe. They're beautiful. Good thick sole. Nancy calls across the room to David.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Honey? David walks over and recognizes one of her bosses, Martin.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hello, Jack. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Daniel Boone, as I live and breathe. Dan, you know my wife, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (shakes hands) Hi, Carol.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Boone, you leave in the morning, uh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let's call me David from now on. Just for old times sake. Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, I'm just playing with you. Listen, I'll tell you something. What you and your wife are doing, well, it's wonderful. Carol and I were driving over here tonight, and talking seriously about breaking the mold ourselves.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You bet. We haven't been that happy lately. Have we, honey? How can a person respond to this? Carol just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: (continuing) I told her, if I can get some time off, we're going to try to get down to La Costa for a weekend and just let it all out. David now realizes that breaking the "mold" has many different meanings to different people.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: La Costa? For a whole weekend, huh? That's great.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: That's if I can get away. If not, at least for an afternoon. Just the idea of getting to San Diego, maybe take in Sea World. Anyway, did Nancy tell you what Robinson's plans to do?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Actually we haven't talked too much about American business lately.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, there is a rumor and I would appreciate you not telling anyone  this, but our store may just be buying up the May Company. This is just the kind of expansion that can make a man like me very, very wealthy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, if it's good for you, I'm real happy.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Well, let's just say it could make me a million dollars, minimum. But, David, please keep this down. God, I probably shouldn't have said anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jack, we're not going to be around people who will care. I promise you. I don't think a guide at the Grand Canyon knows or cares too much about the acquisition of a department store in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: You want a surprise? You want to know about the Grand Canyon and business? The 7-Eleven at the Grand Canyon does more volume business per year than any other 7-Eleven in the country, especially around Muscular Dystrophy time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, that's good to know.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I think it has something to do with the hiking and the tragedy of the children who can't hike. I don't know, but last year they did two million, eight-hundred thousand. Now, of course, there are no other quickie stores around so they have a good one there. A lot of people moving in and out of that canyon. Have you seen these new U-Tote-M stores?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, I don't want to be rude but I can't talk business anymore. I hate to sound "sixties" to you but I'm in a different place.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hey, I understand. I remember the sixties. As a matter of fact, the concept of U-Tote-M is a sixties concept. See, the 7-Eleven is a rush-rush place. U-Tote-M is lay-back. Their store in Tarzana this year is going to gross almost...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Jack, please? Pete Hirsch yells from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: I'd like to make a toast. People mumble, "Great." "Good." "It's about time." Everybody gathers around. People raise their glasses up.

dialogues.speaker: PETE
dialogues.text: (continuing) To our beautiful friends, David and Nancy Howard... Good luck! He drinks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's it, huh? What a well thought out toast. Thank you, Pete. People laugh. Scattered laughter around the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Well, I think it's time for me to say something right now. We hear a little applause. "Speech! Speech!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing; calling Nancy over) Sweetheart, would you come here? David and Nancy stand together, arm-in-arm.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I have a surprise for my wife and I would like to share it, not only with her, but with you, who we consider our closest friends. We do have some other close friends. I'm sure they got lost. People laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) When Nancy and I were married we had dreams and plans and I guess in the pursuit of those things, we kind of lost each other. Tomorrow morning, when we leave here, we have no destination. Our only goal is to find out who we really are and what it is that's really out there. We're going to be adventurers in the classic sense of the word, but there is one place that we will stop at first. (reaches into his pocket and takes out a little box) That place is Las Vegas, Nevada.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (her eyes open up wide; excited) Las Vegas? Really?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, if this is to be a new beginning, I think there's only one way to really show it to this woman that I love. So, tomorrow evening my wife and I are going  to be remarried. People applaud. Nancy is overwhelmed. She opens the little box and there is a ruby ring.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh, my God! Oh! My! People are trying to get a glance at the ring. We can hear OOHING and AAHING.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) This is the most beautiful thing you've ever done.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I'd like to say it was nothing, but that small little ruby cost a fortune. People laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) That's okay, it's budgeted for. A little laughter again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) And now, I would like to propose a toast. Everyone raises their glasses.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) To you, our loyal friends, we will miss you. To my lovely new bride, I want to know you all over again... And to America, get ready. Here we come! Everybody drinks. As they do we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear MUSIC (possibly the song from "Easy Rider" when Dennis Hopper and Peter Fonda left L.A. on their motor- cycles). This is the first time we see the motor home. No expense was spared on this. It's seventy feet long. From the outside, you can see a roof that doubles as a little patio where you can sun yourself. The windows are huge. It looks luxurious, even from a distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is driving. Nancy is in the back in the kitchen area.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey, we're two minutes from crossing the city limits. Come up front. This is historic.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (from the rear of the trailer) Just a second! This microwave oven browns, did you know that? The one in our new house couldn't even do that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Our new house? No, some poor sucker's new house. This is our new house and I love it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy walks up towards the front with two melted cheese sandwiches. No matter how horrible the sandwiches looked or tasted, to David, it would be great. That's his new attitude.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Boy, does this smell good. How long did it take to melt this?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Twenty seconds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you believe it? Boy! I never really tasted melted cheese on toast before. I must have eaten it a million times, but this is the first time I've really tasted it. It's good and I bet it gets better the further we get from L.A.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We'll actually be breathing clean air. We haven't done that for -- how many years?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Forever. I hope we can recognize it. Nancy smiles. This is certainly the best mood she's been in for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Last night was so nice, don't you think? Those are good people. We had good friends there.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know. It's just that we weren't good friends there.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Every once in a while I can't believe what we're doing. Are you scared? Be honest.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, not at all. Well, let's say I'm scared in the same way Columbus was scared.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Columbus must have really been scared, huh? That took a lot of guts, didn't it? What if the world was flat? They really didn't know anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I think he covered himself.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, let's say there was the Pinta, the Nina and the Santa Maria. I'd bet everything I have that Columbus was in the Santa Maria. If the world was flat, I think he'd watch the Pinta and the Nina go. Then he'd tell the Santa Maria to turn around. He'd probably just go back and have sex with the Queen again. I don't think he was a complete schmuck.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So, actually, we're braver than Columbus. We don't have two motor homes in front of us.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's right. However, we should keep our eye on that Buick ahead. If it falls off the earth, it would be wise to pull over and re- evaluate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The town is all lit up. The motor home pulls up in front of a 24-hour wedding chapel. David stops. He stares at the chapel through the window.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Doesn't it look beautiful? I'm excited. (opens the door and starts to get out) Let me find out what we do. I'll get all the information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Aren't you tired?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm excited.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You know what we should do? We should get married tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why? We should get married now and then drive out to the Grand Canyon and have our second honeymoon under the stars. What could be better than that?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, here's what I'd like to do. I'd like to get married in the morning. We're trying to start a new life. We should do it at the beginning of a new day. We'll both be fresh. We'll be up. We can get married at the crack of dawn.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That sounds nice. Alright. We'll camp out some place tonight and then come back before dawn. As a matter-of-fact, these places will be less crowded then. Good idea. Nancy, you're a genius. He starts the engine.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are we sure we want to camp out tonight?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: 21 What?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why don't we make tonight a real old-fashioned honeymoon? Let's go to the best hotel and get the honeymoon suite and celebrate our heads off.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, we don't want to stay in a Vegas hotel. This is what we've left, this money-grabbing, horrible society.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I agree, but one night? We'll have room service and make love in a big bed and watch porno movies. I think it'll be fun.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We want to touch Indians.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We will. Just tonight and then that's it. Don't you want to take a bath together in one of those big tubs?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, okay.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: If you really don't want to, we don't have to. We can camp out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, it's okay. As a matter-of-fact, it might be very exciting. We haven't been in a bath together for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David pulls the motor home into the parking lot and turns over the keys to the young parking attendant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Nancy are coming through the main doors. We can see the motor home being driven out of the drive- way by one of the valet parking attendants. David looks behind him and watches the home drive off. He's nervous.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't think they know how to drive those things. He could ruin it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (all excited) Oh, don't worry. They can drive anything. Look. Isn't this wonderful? It's so romantic. God, I used to come here a lot. I kind of miss it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You never told me you came here. When?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Before we were married. I'll tell you about it later. Come on. They approach the front desk. A CLERK is working at one of the reservation computers.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Excuse me?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My wife and I have dropped out of society and we're making this statement, but we want to spend one last night here. We're planning to get up at the crack of dawn and get remarried and...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (interrupting David, she whispers to him) Just ask him for the room.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (whispering back) I'm getting to it. I know what I'm doing. (to the Clerk) Anyway, we're going to get up very early and get remarried so we want something very special because we're doing something special. My point is, we'd like your finest bridal suite.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Do you have a reservation?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I told you, we just dropped out. We don't do reservation things anymore. We're living spontaneously.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Well, we're not. We thrive on reservations and I'm sorry but the bridal suite is occupied.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What other rooms do you have?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (to the Clerk) Just a minute, please? (she pulls David aside, whispering) The bridal suite isn't occupied.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's not occupied. I can see it in his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give him money.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Give him fifty bucks.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We'll get the bridal suite.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Trust me. David approaches the desk again. He takes out fifty dollars. He puts it in the Clerk's hand, like he's shaking hands with him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hello, again. (slips him the fifty) Do me a favor? I've worked with computers. I know what can happen. Sometimes these things get fouled up. Would you check one more time? Maybe the bridal suite was empty and the room next to it was occupied and the computer got mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (takes a look) I know what you mean. That can happen sometimes. Let me check. (he looks at the reservation com- puter for a moment) Nope. It's occupied. These are state-of-the-art computers. Very rarely do we have those kind of  mistakes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You're sure?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Yes. Says right here, "Bridal Suite full." Nancy leans over and whispers to David.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Give him more.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus. Really? Nancy nods yes. David turns back to the Clerk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Listen, I'm not very good at this. I don't get good seats in shows because of this problem. I don't get good tables in restaurants. I've really never been good at this particular kind of exchange of money so, how much do you want?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: A hundred dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fine. (hands him more cash) Here you go. A hundred. Now, I assume we don't have to continue this computer talk again and say that it's working now and everything? The Clerk doesn't even bother to answer. He reaches behind the desk and hands David his key.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Here you are, eight-twenty. He rings for the porter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, this is the best bridal suite?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: Heart-shaped bed. Everything. You'll love it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you very much. I'm sure the hundred doesn't apply towards the room at all.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: You're kidding, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Of course. I was kidding all along. David and Nancy leave the desk and walk towards the elevator.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Tell me we didn't do the right thing, getting out of this horrible society? Jesus Christ, I told the guy we dropped out. Did that make any difference? No. I said we're making a statement. What did he do? Stare at me. I said we're getting remarried. What does he finally say? Give me more money. God! How does a guy like that even live?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, think of all the people checking in here. Everyone giving him a hundred dollars, he probably lives well.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I meant with himself. How does he... Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Nancy enter. Apparently, the hundred dollars was not quite enough. This could not be Desert Inn's best bridal suite. This looks like the junior bridal suite, at best. At one end of the room are two twin heart-shaped beds. Above them, there's a mirror, heavily-flocked with gold specks. The rest of the room is decorated in standard red velour. Nancy is disappointed. David is confused. He can't figure out how any manufacturer could make a living turning out twin heart-shaped beds.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: I'll go down and get your luggage for you. Where is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's okay. It's locked in our house. I'll get it later. Thank you very much. David reaches into his pocket and gives the man a dollar.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I haven't been here in years. I hope this is enough. If it isn't, take some from the clerk. I gave him a hundred. The Porter looks at David and walks out without saying a word.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: So? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I think if Liberace had children, this would be their room. Cute little hearts, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We should ask for a bigger bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let's hold onto the cash we have. I don't want any more favors.  We can try and push these together. They try but they find very quickly that hearts don't fit together. After a few attempts, they give up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Look, we can crawl over the ventricles when we want to have sex. It'll be exciting. Why don't you order something up, okay? Order up a great meal and some great champagne. I'll go run the bath. David walks into the bathroom. Nancy sits down on the bed. She picks up the room service menu and starts to read through it. She calls to David.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: How's the bath?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (walking out of the bathroom) There's no bath in there, honey.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I have no reason to lie to you. Go look for yourself. There's a very teeny, heart-shaped shower and a medium sized, heart- shaped sink. At best, we can wash our socks together.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you disappointed?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Maybe we shouldn't order room service. We should get dressed and go down and check out some of these restaurants. Hey, do  you want to see a show?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't want to leave the room. I just want to be with you tonight, here. It's our honeymoon. We should order up like we planned and then we can figure out a way to make love. Somewhere in this room, there has to be space.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay. (gets up and walks toward the bath- room) I'm going in to take a nice hot shower, okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good. You get nice and sexy because when you come out, we'll pack and leave.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Come on. We're going to have fun.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm joking with you. Now, hurry up, I'm getting horny. When you come out, I'll be the naked one on the right heart. I might even be looking at myself in the mirror and masturbating. Although, I don't think I can see myself through all this gold flock.

dialogues.speaker: SHOT OF ALARM CLOCK
dialogues.text: It's ringing. The time is five-thirty A.M. As we PULL BACK we see David reaching over and shutting it He rolls over towards the other heart bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Rise and shine, my darling wife. (singing to the  tune of "My Fair Lady") We're getting married this morning. We're... He stops singing. She doesn't seem to be in the other bed. The room's still a little dark. Maybe David isn't seeing clearly yet. He's patting all over the bed.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nancy? Honey? He realizes she's not there. He gets up and walks towards the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Honey? Are you in there? Nancy? There's no answer. Obviously, she's not in the bathroom. Possibly, she's gone down the hall to get ice. He opens the door and calls down the hall.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Honey? Nancy? Are you at the ice machine? He goes back into the room. He picks up the phone. A WOMAN'S VOICE answers.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: May I help you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. I'd like to page Nancy Howard, please.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: And where would she be? Do you have any idea?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Probably in the coffee shop. David sits and waits. After a short pause:

dialogues.speaker: MAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi, honey. Had a sex change, huh? (laughs at his joke) I think you picked up the wrong phone. I'm paging my wife.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: You're married to Nancy Howard?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Why don't you come down to the casino?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why? Is there something wrong?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Your wife has been gambling for quite some time and possibly, you should speak with her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do I have to say to her? Is she winning?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Why don't you just come downstairs?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (hangs up the phone) Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David comes tearing into the casino. He is still in his bathrobe. A SECURITY GUARD stops him.

dialogues.speaker: GUARD
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, you can't come into the casino dressed like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you, crazy? I saw Electric Horseman. Animals rode through here. Excuse me. He pushes past the Guard. He looks frantically around trying to find Nancy. At this hour of the morning, it's easy to spot people. There aren't too many of them. He sees her. She's off in the corner at the roulette table. There's a small group of people around her. They seem to be watching, she seems to be gambling. David walks as fast as he can. He doesn't want to run, his robe might open up. As he approaches Nancy, he is frightened by what he sees. She is a maniac. She has been up for hours. The transformation is scary. It's like Jekyll and Hyde. She's frantically moving chips all around the table.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Honey? What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (to the Dealer) Eight! Big chips!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Not now. Get away. Not now.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Stop it. Come on, eight! Come on, eight! The DEALER spins the wheel. The ball drops into the number sixteen slot.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Sixteen.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (shrieks) Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, calm down. Sweetheart? The Man who spoke to David on the telephone approaches him at the table.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Could I speak to you for a moment?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What is it? The Man takes David aside.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Your wife is very distraught. She's been gambling almost five hours and she has not been on a lucky streak. Now, it's not our place to stop her, but possibly, you should.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean she's not been on a lucky streak? She's losing?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well, why don't you talk to her? David runs back to the table.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey, I want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Get away! (to the Dealer) Once again! Give me eight! The Dealer spins the wheel. The ball goes around and around.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come on, baby. Come on, lucky baby. Baby, baby. Baby, baby.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Eight it is.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (jumping up, excited as can be) Yes! Great!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (now a little excited himself) Hey, that is great. You're a winner. (to Dealer) How much was that? How much did she win?

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Sixty dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Alright. Nothing wrong with that. What's wrong with that? Now, what does this man mean who says you weren't on a lucky streak?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I was down earlier. Just go away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But you're up now, right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm still down. (to Dealer) Eight again! And make it happen for me! David turns to the Man who spoke to him on the phone. The Man is standing at a distance watching what's happening with a slight look of pity on his face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (walking over to him) Boy, she keeps betting eight, huh? How down is she exactly?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Oh, she's very, very down. I  don't know how much money you have, but on the average I'd say this is what we call "very down."

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean? A thousand? At this moment, we hear a GROAN from the roulette table. The ball has dropped into double zero. David runs back over. He sees the Dealer taking the chips off of eight.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Dammit! That keeps coming up, that zero. Jesus Christ! Now, once again, eight! Come back eight! Come back, eight!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just a minute. Nancy, stop.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please, David! Please! You're bringing me bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, according to some people here, I'm not bringing anything. You're already having bad luck.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's changing! Now come on, eight! Eight's my mate! Take the bait, number eight. The Dealer spins the ball. It drops into the number four.

dialogues.speaker: DEALER
dialogues.text: Four.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: See what you did? Bad luck! Get away, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This man over here says you're very down. What does he mean?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Fuck the man! I don't know who you're talking about. (to Dealer) Try it again! Eight!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy, stop betting eight. There's hundreds of numbers on this table. Why the hell do you keep betting eight? Now, how much have we lost?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Everything. Come on, eight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean everything? Did you say everything? At this moment, the ball falls into number nine. The Dealer takes the last of Nancy's chips.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Goddammit! Son-of-a-bitch! You can't get any closer to eight than nine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (beginning to take charge) Come over here. Come with me. He drags Nancy away from the roulette table. She turns around. She's yelling at the Dealer.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Eight again! One more time!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There's nothing on the board. You're not at the table. You haven't placed a bet. Stop yelling eight. He doesn't care anymore.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I gotta find some money. Please. I'm about to hit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, you're about to get hit. Come on. We have some serious talking to do. David starts to pull Nancy out of the casino. He passes by a one-dollar progressive slot machine with Nancy in tow as BELLS START TO RING and LIGHTS FLASH. An OLDER WOMAN has hit the jackpot and starts to scream.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I won!! I won!!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Look. She won... I want to play!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's too late. You chose the table. Let's get out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit down at one of the tables. David looks a little worried. Nancy is still frantic. She's mixed up. She's also looking around for a Keno girl. She's obviously in some sort of a daze.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, talk. What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: At two-thirty this morning, I was up three hundred thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Three hundred thousand dollars? That's a lot of money!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: More chips than you've ever seen in your life. You wouldn't have believed it. They were all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But when I came downstairs they were all gone. You didn't have any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I can get them back.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Let's wait on that for just a second. So, everything is gone and I'm trying to figure out the word "everything." We had a little bit of cash with us and you lost that?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So, what did you do? You got more cash?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: So, you wrote a check then?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You started drawing cash from our nest egg?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: How much of the nest egg did you take? What's left?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. By "everything" you mean "nothing."

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't lose a hundred and eighty thousand dollars?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Maybe. I don't know. Give or take a thousand.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Give or take a thousand? Give or take a thousand? David is holding on to one of his testicles so as not to kill this woman. This is the first time in his life, where he truly can't comprehend what he has heard.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh my God! Oh my God! I understand what we mean now. I understand what we all mean. Oh my God! My God! My God! David puts his hand to his forehead. He looks around. He's thinking. Something must be done. Something must be done quickly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh my God! Alright. Let's not panic. David thinks of something. He stands up from the table and yells as loud as he can.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
