dialogues.text: (continuing) Bellhop, please. Bellhop, in here, please. There's an emergency! He sits down, he's rubbing his head.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What's the matter?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nothing. Just wait. Oh my God!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, there were these Persians around me, staring at all these chips that were on the table and I've never had that feeling before, the feeling that I was completely in control. I was the one. I didn't need anything. I didn't care. I didn't have any problems. Do you know that feeling?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Not now. I don't know that feeling now, no. The BELLHOP approaches.

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: Yes, sir?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: First of all, I was speaking to a gentleman in the casino who seemed to be in charge there. He's what?

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: The Pit Boss?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: Mr. Shuster.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fine. Does he have an office?

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: Yes, it's behind the front desk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fine. Alright. Now would you please do me a favor? My wife is tired and would you escort her to 820. (hands the Bellhop his room key) Would you please sit with her, maybe she'll want to take a shower  or whatever, and just don't leave the room. I'll be up in a little while. But please don't leave. I don't want her to be alone right now.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why are you treating me like an animal?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'll explain it to you later. They all get up. They exit the coffee shop. 27

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (speaking to Nancy as if she has just had a nervous breakdown) Just relax. Lie down, if you want. Have some water. I'll be up ina few minutes.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Stop talking to me this way.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm not talking to you in any particular way. I'm just trying to keep everything calm and I'm trying to remain calm. I'm also trying to think what I can do to help us out now. (to the Bellhop) The man's name again? The Pit Boss?

dialogues.speaker: BELLHOP
dialogues.text: Shuster.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you. They are now at the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: David, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save it. Just go upstairs. He leaves her at the elevators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks very slowly towards Shuster's office. You can tell he's thinking. He approaches the front desk and clears his throat, trying to act dignified. The robe diminishes this a bit.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to the Clerk) Mr. Shuster, the Pit Boss, may I speak to him, please?

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I don't know if he's in. Just a moment. The Clerk picks up the phone. He buzzes.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Yes. There's a gentleman here to see you. (to David) What is your name?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm David Howard. He knows me, we spoke on the telephone. My wife was the one who was up for hours.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: (into phone) David Howard. Yes. Yes. (hangs up phone) He'll be right out. David stands there. He's thinking, staring straight ahead. Out of an office emerges JACK SHUSTER, the Pit Boss, the man we saw earlier. Shuster's a large man, in his early fifties. He's as intimidating as his job calls for. He looks like he might have killed  somebody once, and actually enjoyed it. He walks over to David.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard? Come on in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David tries to compose himself even more as he follows Shuster into his office. David's story is now formed. He knows what he wants to say. He feels confident. David enters the office. He sits down in front of Shuster's desk.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: First of all, let me say, I've heard a great deal about you.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: (suspicious) What do you mean? From who? What did you hear?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, I just meant I've heard wonderful things from everybody in general, from the whole hotel.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: (relieved) Well, that's very nice. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Is your wife feeling better?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes, she is.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: So, what can I do for you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I have a very interesting idea. I think you'll be taken by it. Shuster stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I was a key executive with a major advertising agency - one of the biggest in the world.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Yes, right. So?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I was the Idea Man there. So, when I say I have an interesting idea, I'm not speaking like any slob that walks in off the street.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (clearing his throat, about to enter into The Big Story) My wife and I, we dropped out of society. She had a very important position in a department store and again, I remind you that I was one of the highest executives in the world's largest advertising firm. Shuster just stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Anyway, we were going to find ourselves. Then, we thought, maybe we're too old, it's too late. We can't find ourselves, that's only for kids. And then we thought about it some more and it hit us. Wait a minute. Who's to say at what age you stop being a kid?

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: You gotta have some age. How else  could a court separate rape from fun? In this state, it's eighteen, by the way.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. But my point is we wanted to find ourselves and we did and we dropped out, just like they did in "Easy Rider."

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Easy what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The movie, "Easy Rider." Famous movie. Important movie.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Didn't see that, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It's a classic. If it comes on cable here, see it. Anyway, we did something that no one has done for a long time. Maybe no one has ever done it because in the movie they were movie stars, so they didn't really do it, even though they portrayed people that did it.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: I'm getting mixed up here. What is your point?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, we did it for real. We quit our jobs and we sold everything that we had. The only thing we own is our little motor home, which is parked outside. That's all we've got and we were going to spend years roaming around this beautiful country, but we knew we couldn't do it unless we had our little nest egg tucked away in the bank.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: (interrupts) I'm going off duty in a few minutes.  Now, your point is what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm getting to it. Why did we come to Las Vegas? Because it was a new beginning and I wanted to remarry my lovely wife. That's nice, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I wanted to get remarried but I wanted to spend our honeymoon in the Grand Canyon, places like we intend to spend the rest of our lives in, but my wife is very fond of your hotel and all of the employees and she said, "Oh, come on, let's spend our honeymoon here." And we did and the room was very lovely and everybody was very nice to us, but my wife lost the nest egg.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard, stop right here. I think I know what you're getting at. I realize you've lost a great deal here and I want you to know that your room and your meals are comped.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's very nice but that's not exactly what I'm saying. I think I have a multi-million dollar idea. Now, you have to be very secretive about what I'm going to tell you because the other hotels, if they heard about it, well, they'll grab it in a minute. David leans over Shuster's desk and whispers to make the idea really sound secretive:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) I think, as an experiment, you  give us back the money we lost.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, imagine the publicity? I mean, the Hilton, for example, they have billboards all over L.A. where they put the faces of the winners of those slot machines. Now, those people win a couple hundred thousand dollars, but the hotel is getting millions of dollars of publicity with those billboards because people drive by and say, "Gee, the Hilton looks like a nice place. Look at those smiling people." So, what about a billboard with my wife and I on it and we would be smiling and there would be a saying, something like, "These people dropped out of society, they couldn't take it any longer, but they made a mistake. They lost their nest egg at The Desert Inn, but The Desert Inn gave it back." And maybe there could be some kind of a visual with you handing us an egg or something. Now I mean, I'm just formulating this now, as I'm talking, but you can imagine, when it's worked out how effective it could be.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: (chuckling) That's wonderful. (he gets up) Well, Mr. Howard, nice to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean nice to meet me? You said this is wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: We're kidding each other here, right?  (starts to laugh again) I gotta tell you, this is one of the best things I've ever heard. What's the board gonna say again? "Gamblers, come and get your money back." (he laughs) Great. That's great.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (standing up) No. No. Wait... Not "Gamblers, get your money back." That's wrong. We're not gamblers. We're the few people in society that have tried to do something with our lives. See? We're drop- outs. We're finding ourselves. Someone's got to help the few people like us, because if they don't, nobody will ever drop out again. Nobody will ever have the courage to find themselves.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Well, I understand what you mean, but I don't think The Desert Inn can help find you. I'm sorry, but thank you for the idea and good night. He begins to escort David to the door.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (stopping him) Listen, I've experienced this before. I've had clients that didn't understand the idea until they saw it on television and then they said, "My God! What a brilliant idea! Why didn't I understand this?" I might have used the wrong phrase. Okay picture this: maybe, my wife and I will do a television commercial for you and there could be a jingle and it could go:  (begins to sing) "The Desert Inn has heart! The Desert Inn has heart! The Desert Inn has heart!" Something like that. See what I mean?

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: That's a nice jingle. Mr. Howard, let's assume you're serious here. What if this caught on? Could you imagine what would happen? Why, we would have to return everybody's losses. The casino would just crumble. We couldn't pay our bills. You know the casino accounts for a great deal of our profits.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I understand. Of course, you don't pay back everybody's losses. You make a distinct division between the bold, who are out there searching, and all the other schmucks, who come here to see Wayne Newton.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: I see. Now, I like Wayne Newton. So, I fall into what category?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (realizing this was not the best example) Oh, look, I picked a name out of a hat. I like Wayne Newton, too. I'm saying a schmuck, representing the gambler and a bold person, representing me and my wife and the one or two others that probably wouldn't come here anyway. You wouldn't have to do this more than once or twice, there's not too many bold people around. I think it was a mistake to use entertainers as the dividing line. We could find another system. Anyway, what do you say? We do need that nest egg back.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: I say good luck to you and stay away from the tables next time.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, that's for sure, but come on? Half the money, for courage? Shuster opens up his office door. He escorts David out. 30

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Mr. Howard, nice to meet you. A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hold it. What about "Miracle on 34th Street?"

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Christmas picture, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (now rambling on very fast, desperate, rea- lizing his plan is about to fail) More than a Christmas picture. What happened there? Macy's didn't want to send their customers to Gimble's because the president of Macy's thought they would lose all of their customers and lose a tremendous amount of money and it would be taken wrong. But it wasn't taken wrong. What happened? Macy's did much better than they ever did before. And that's what would happen to you. The Desert Inn would do much, much better because you would get Gimble's business and the casino would be full.

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not too familiar with that picture but didn't Macy's have Santa Claus to help them out? (he starts to laugh) I mean, if they didn't have Santy  Claus there, they might have done very badly. He continues to laugh. David now starts to laugh along with him, except David's laugh has a pitiful ring to it. He senses this is not going to work.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. I guess they did have Santy Claus. Well, thank you. Thank you. And just so I understand, we can t get any of our money back, right?

dialogues.speaker: SHUSTER
dialogues.text: Well, not today, no. But if the policy ever changes, we'll write you. (still chuckling as he goes back into his office) That's wonderful. Very good. He closes the door. The desk Clerk, who has just seen Shuster laugh, turns to David, who is standing there looking as bad as he's ever looked.

dialogues.speaker: CLERK
dialogues.text: I think he likes you. He rarely laughs at anything. David just nods a sickly "thank you."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David and Nancy are driving. They are well outside of Las Vegas. Nancy is staring out of the window. David is driving in silence. Obviously, they have been driving for a great deal of time without saying anything. Nancy finally breaks the silence.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can't take this. Say something. Yell at me. Hit me. Drive off  the road. Do anything. Just stop being so silent.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I have nothing to say.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I can't keep apologizing. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I'm sorry. I feel horrible. I would do anything to change it. David says nothing. He just clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You're going to make yourself sick. It's unnatural. I understand. If I were you, I'd be furious. Don't hold it in. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (looking at her) I'm fine. More silent driving. Nancy is desperately uncomfort- able. Obviously, David is not fine. How could he be? He's seen ten years of earnings dissipate in less than three hours and he didn't participate in any of the dissipation. After a while, Nancy tries a new approach.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Obviously, I can't apologize anymore for what I did so we should talk about what we're going to do.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And what would that be?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, our dream is still the same. We just don't have any money. David clears his throat again.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) And, also, we should stop saying  we don't have any money. We do have some.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (very patiently) We have eight hundred and two dollars.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's something.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It is something. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, look, I think we should try to make the rest of the day as pleasant as we can. Since we're heading towards Hoover Dam anyway, we should make that our destination for today. We can go there, look around, maybe have a picnic or something, and maybe just see the dam and just have a nice day outside. What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (staring straight ahead, speaking in a monotone) Is that what you'd like?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Maybe it would be fun.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (still staring, still speaking in a monotone) Fine. Hoover Dam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are people walking around, tours going on and children playing. The motor home pulls up. They park.  Nancy gets out with a bounce in her step, hoping David might copy her. David gets out like Frankenstein, walking very slowly, with no expression.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Look at this! Come here. God! Just think. Men built this!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (still with no expression) Yes. Men did build this.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What about something to eat? Hungry?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm starved.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't think you can eat now.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Because with the little bit of money that we have left, I think we have to sit down and make up a new budget. Until we do, maybe we shouldn't spend it all on cotton candy and other various knickknacks here at the dam. Nancy is beginning to get irritated and frustrated that he will not talk to her like an adult.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, if that's your attitude, I think you should give me half the money and let me eat whatever I want and you can do what you want with your half. I think that's the fair thing.  People

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (the release of his anger now begins) The fair thing? The fair thing? That's it! You're right. I've been controlled! Boy, have I been controlled! I guess any doctor could have spotted it. I was about to die, I was so controlled. You took all the money we had! can hear this echoing for miles around.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing; now yelling) You took our nest egg and you broke it up! You got yoke all over the casino! You got the white all over the coffee shop! You threw the shells in the parking lot! Fair? Fair?! Where was I when you were playing with the egg? Sleeping. Sleeping. Goddammit!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Good. Get it out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Shut up! Don't talk to me like I'm an insane patient!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Let's just go back inside. You can yell at me. You should, I think it's right. I just don't want you to yell out here.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Out where? This is where we're going to have to live. Why not yell out here? We're going to have to do everything else out here. We'll be sleeping out here and eating out here and going to the bathroom out here! Get used to this cement, baby! This is it!  Out here is it! We found ourselves! We found ourselves, alright! We found ourselves with eight hundred dollars in the middle of nowhere! Nancy walks away. She sees a crowd that is gathered around and she does not want to have an argument in front of these people. David follows her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't want to have an argument in front of those people.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why not? I think those people are entitled to know how stupid you are.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is going to turn into a personal attack, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What else? A general attack? Who am I going to attack? Nevada? I can't attack the state. It wasn't their fault. I can't attack the motor home. It stayed in the parking lot. I can't attack me. I was fast asleep. By process of elimination, who's left?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I am. I'm left, okay? And I'll say it one more time - I'm sorry. They are off by themselves now. They have reasonable privacy. They are both very upset.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't want your apologies. I want to know why? I want to try to understand how it happened. Tell  me. How did it happen?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You couldn't sleep. I see. Now, I remember nights where I couldn't sleep. I'm just trying to think what I did. Let's see. I tried warm milk or I took a long walk or I took Nytol and then, if all that didn't work, I gave away all the money I ever earned. But you didn't try any of those things first. You just gave away the money first, right? What did you intend to do? Have warm milk afterwards? Tell me. I'm mixed up.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're not even listening.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. You're right. Go ahead. You couldn't sleep. Then what happened?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't remember. I just went downstairs.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why didn't you wake me up?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What would you have done?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What would I have done? I would have followed you. I would've seen you. I would have watched you take your money and begin to lose it and I would have stopped you at thirty dollars, maybe thirty-two dollars, at the most. I would have said, "Sweetheart, come back to bed.  We don't want to fool with our nest egg." You know, Nancy, I think you just considered nest egg to be a term but to me, it was a key to this whole experiment. Why, I considered it like a third person. It was our best friend, our guardian angel. It was going to allow us to do everything we wanted to do. It was going to watch over us during bad times and laugh with us during good times. It was going to help us roam and purchase and eat and explore. It was going to help us make love and laugh and cry and now, it's gone and who's got it? The Desert Inn! They've got our nest egg. They can sure use it, can't they? They don't have their own. They're a poor little organization. They need our nest egg. Gee, I hope they use it wisely. I know someday those mirrors are going to have to be reflocked and the red velvet was looking kind of worn. And those little heart beds are going to need new sheets. I'm glad we could help them pay for that. I'm glad our life savings will go towards making that room look a little prettier. I'm glad we gave it all to them, Nancy. I'm just going to miss the little nest egg, that's all. Won't you, sweetheart? Won't you miss the nest egg? In the middle of the night, won't you feel kind of lonely because little nest egg is paying for the gas in Frank Sinatra's limo?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Shut up, David! (begins to cry; she's getting hysterical) Shut up! I don't want to hear nest egg anymore! I don't want to hear that word. Let me tell you something.  That's not the way you drop out anyway. If you're really going to drop out, you drop out with nothing!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You drop out with nothing? Oh where did you read that? In the Las Vegas Guide?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I didn't read that. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. Who told you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Friends, people who know. I don't have to answer you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. You don't have to answer me. You can't answer me because no one ever told you that. You never had friends who dropped out. You don't know anybody who dropped out except for us. So how the hell did you know that? Come on, tell me?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Alright. The movie you're basing your whole life on, "Easy Rider," they dropped out with nothing. They had no nest egg.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Bullshit. They had a huge nest egg. They sold cocaine. They didn't get on their motorcycles till their nest egg was giant, fifty times the size of ours.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's not true.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, look. I'm not going to stand here, in front of one of the seven wonders of the world and argue about  an old movie. I'm going to go now and get back in the motor home and maybe you can wander around out here and figure out something to do. We have eight hundred dollars left and an entire lifetime. See what you can come up with. David starts to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We could sell cocaine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (stops and turns around) Well, my God. Why didn't I think of that? Great idea. As a matter- of-fact, I remember after seeing "Midnight Express" I went out of the theater saying to myself, "That's for me. Sex with hundreds of Turkish men." David turns around and walks towards the motor home.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Come on. Let's go. Nancy doesn't go with him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: No. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Forget what?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Forget everything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You know, I'll tell you one good thing that came out of all of this. We forgot to get remarried. That was one good thing that happened  and no one has mentioned that yet.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you saying?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm saying that if we got remarried it would be much more difficult to get divorced. Now it's easy. It's over. I'll just stay in Nevada for six weeks and then we'll be legally through. This is how it should have happened anyway, David. We were stupid to think it could have happened any other way.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Do you really believe that?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You bet your life I do. I realize now, you're never going to let me forget this. For the rest of our lives, you'll blame me and I won't take it. So, goodbye. I'm sorry. It didn't work out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nancy walks to the side of the road and sticks out her thumb. David walks after her.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you expect to do? Where do you think you're going?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I still have my dreams. I'1l have to find somebody else who understands them a little bit better and then I'll start over.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. Enough is enough. I understand your dreams. You said, "Explode." I exploded. It's done. Now, come on. Let's not act stupid. I'm over it.  We see

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (crying) You'll never be over it. I know you. You're right. I'm stupid. You don't want to be with a stupid person so leave me alone.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: None of your business. Now get out of here, please.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You told me to be angry. You said it was unhealthy not to be angry. You'd be angry, too. God knows you'd be angry. a car approaching in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nancy, there's a car coming and there's a man in there who looks like an animal. Now if you don't put your thumb back, he's going to pick you up and if he picks you up, you're going to be in his car. I don t know him. You don't know him. We don't know where we are, so why don't we stop acting like this?!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (yelling) What is happening? You said it fifteen hundred times, "Get angry." I got angry. I thought I got angry well. I'm over it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Sure you're over it. You're still yelling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm yelling because you're about to get in someone else's car! An old Chevy pulls over. A guy in his late thirties, large, ugly, RED-NECK-looking fellow says to Nancy:

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Where ya headin'?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: With you.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Alright. You got it. Come on. Nancy gets in the car. David starts to run after them.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (yelling) This has gotten out of hand. Look around you, Nancy, you're in another car! That man is not me! Nancy! I apologize! I'm sorry! David stops yelling. He just stands there for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing; to himself) Listen to what I'm saying. I was sleeping and I'm yelling I'm sorry. What's going on? Jesus Christ! She's going to get killed!

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: David runs back to the motor home. He starts the engine. David tries to catch up to the Chevy. The Chevy's gotten a large lead. He goes faster but it doesn't help. He loses the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mumbling) I've lost my wife in the desert. This is just silly. You lose your wallet or your keys but I've lost a whole woman. David continues to drive. After a short while, he spots a road stop, a gas-food-rest stop. There's a small restaurant. He spots the Chevy. He pulls in. David gets out of the motor home. Through the window, he can see this Red-Neck and Nancy sitting at a table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David walks in. He approaches the table where Nancy and the Red-Neck are sitting.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy, I think we should go.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: I don't think she wants to speak to you, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I've known her for a long time. I think I would rather have direct communication with her. Nancy, come on.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: I said she don't want to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We're leaving now, okay, honey?

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: You're not listenin', are you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm listening. This is my wife. It's between her and me. Nancy?  We're going to work things out now. Thank this gentleman for the ride and let's go. Nancy says nothing. The Red-Neck stands up. He is huge.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Mister, I'm gonna count to three and I want you out of here. One...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy, this man's counting. Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Two.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Honey, there's one number left.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Three. The Red-Neck takes David by the shoulder and starts to lead him outside.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: (continuing) Let's go. You and I, we have some fighting to do. David is being shoved outside. He looks back at Nancy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is this what you want? Is this what was supposed to happen? I'm now going to be killed by a gorilla? David and the Red-Neck are outside. Nancy realizes David is probably right. He will be killed. She gets up. She runs after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time she gets outside, David is already being punched in the stomach and then in the face. In be- tween punches, David is yelling to Nancy:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Call him off! He'll obey you! Tell him it's alright! The Red-Neck is now really angry.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: I hate you. I'm going to kill you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: It's okay. Stop. Please? Thank you for the ride but we can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: You're out of this now. This is between him and me. I haven't hated somebody so much in a long time. He reminds me of everything I hate. David is on the ground. The Red-Neck picks him up. Nancy,

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Come on. Come on. Let's really go at it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: This is going to disappoint you but I have really gone at it. I haven't had a fight since I was in the third grade. I'm just not used to it. Nancy, tell him.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please! It's okay. My husband and I had a fight but we can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: I said get out, lady. I'm ona mission now. realizing that she can't stop the fight, begins to scream:

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Help! Help! Police! Help! Murder! Help!  People start to come out of the restaurant. This is more attention than the Red-Neck wanted.

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: Well, look at this. A woman has to help you by yelling for the police. Well, if I wasn't wanted, I wouldn't care. I'd stay here and beat the shit out of you, but right now I can't afford to see the police. But I'll get you. I don't know where or when, but I'll get you, mister. The Red-Neck starts to walk back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yell "Police!" more. Keep yelling.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Police! Police! We see the Red-Neck hasten a bit. He starts his engine.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: More. Yell. Yell. Police! Help! Help! The Chevy pulls out. The Red-Neck yells back:

dialogues.speaker: RED-NECK
dialogues.text: I'll get you. David is holding his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That man will spend the rest of his life trying to find me. I'll be killed, Nancy. Nancy helps him towards the motor home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get inside. David is holding his jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure you're okay?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yeah, I'm okay. Next time, if you're going to hitch, get a ride with a small woman, will you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I'm proud of you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: For what? Getting beat up?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: For rescuing me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I had no choice really. I thought about just forgetting it and finding someone new, but I realized I had nothing to offer them.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: David, listen to me... We're going to be alright.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I hope so. Maybe we will. David starts the engine. The home slowly begins to move.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What do you think we should do first?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: First? First, I think we fill this thing with gas so we can get as far away as possible from that mental patient. Then, I guess we'll head east. We'll drive until we finda place we both like and that'll be our new home. We'll start there and we'll begin to rebuild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: thru 41c

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I swear to God I think this is a blessing in disguise. The whole idea of going to Las Vegas was to get remarried so we could have a new beginning, right? Well, that would've just been a ceremony. Now, we really are starting from the beginning. I think this way is much better.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I hope it is. But since we really will never know the other way, let's not compare.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But after all, the whole purpose was to find ourselves and to be free and now we really are free. The other way...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Hold it, honey. Another comparison, right?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I'm just excited. I think this is a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It very well might be. All I'm saying is let's just let our original plan rest in peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the motor home driving along. In the background there is MUSIC. As they head east, the sun slowly is setting behind them. After various SHOTS of David and Nancy moving along the desert...  B) ... we finally see them pass a sign that says,

dialogues.speaker: "WELCOME TO PRESCOTT, ARIZONA."
dialogues.text: C) They drive on further until they pull up toa trailer park. The sign above the park says "PRESCOTT TRAILER PARK." He stops. He pulls the motor home into this park. He sticks his head out the window, as if to feel the climate. It feels right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun has set. This is where they've chosen to live. Nancy is lying on the bed as David is at the kitchen table, figuring out the money they have left.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay, so, gas and the payment here and the electricity hook-up, the water hook-up, lunch... Oh my!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Three hundred and twenty dollars. He takes that amount out of his pocket. He lays it out in front of then, like a magician doing a card trick.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) There it is, sweetheart. That's it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Okay. Let's call this "emergency" money. We'll get jobs right away so we don't have to touch this.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Absolutely. This money we seal away.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We'll both have jobs by tomorrow. It's going to be good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have no choice. We have to have jobs by tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We should celebrate tonight.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Celebrate what?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This! This is the real beginning! David sits there. He smiles. He's staring at Nancy. After a while he feels a little uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's the matter? What are you staring at?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your legs. They look different.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Different?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: They look longer.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You're joking, right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I have long legs, remember?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Remember what?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That was the first thing you ever said to me. You said I had sexy long legs. That was before you even asked me my name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God. You're right. We talked about your legs for a long time before your name came up. Was I rude?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You were great.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You didn't think I was so sexy the first time you saw me, did you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You didn't say anything.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes I did.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. I remember I told you I thought curly hair was very, very sexy. I said I liked your hair.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, sweetheart, you said curly hair was sexy and then you asked me if that was my own hair.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, I was shy.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Don't worry. I took it asa compliment. Nancy smiles. David walks over and gives her a passionate kiss, the likes of which we have not yet seen in this fil They begin to make love. It's the real thing. As they do we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear MOANING. We see the home rocking gently back and forth. Older people who live in the trailer park start to come out and watch this new residence move from side to side. Some have folding chairs, others have picnic baskets. This is one trailer park that hasn't yet put in cable television. So, to these people, this is entertainment they so badly needed. We SLOWLY...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is still in bed. Nancy is almost dressed. She has an extraordinary amount of energy.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: David, I love you. That was the best. It was amazing. David is a bit dazed. Obviously they've had the best sex of their lives. It's given her energy. It's made him a little confused.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: It never happened like that in L.A. I wonder why?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We stopped having sex in L.A.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That must be it.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Seriously. What do you really think happened? What did we do right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't think it had anything to  do with us.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What was it? The air?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Maybe. My guess is extreme poverty.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, then I say we should stay poor.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Look, I was just guessing. I think we have to make some money, we don't want to starve to death and then find out it really was the air. We'll feel so stupid.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (smiles) I have so much energy. I can't wait to get out and just explore this city. I'm going to get a great job. I know it. David gets out of bed. He puts on his robe.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Me, too. Now, I think we should have some kind of a plan. What do you say we look for work together?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I don't think so. I think we should go in separate directions.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: We'll cover more territory.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Alright. That sounds right. Good. Good idea.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Let's say we meet back here no later than five o'clock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five o'clock. Good.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (kissing him) I can't wait for five o'clock. Nancy exits. David stands at the door calling out to her:

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Good luck! Go for the high pay!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And buy a cheap lunch!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Don't worry.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I mean it! Cheap lunch! We see Nancy wave as she walks off into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is walking down the street staring into various stores. He stops in front of a pharmacy. There's a sign that says: "DELIVERY MAN WANTED." David enters the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David approaches PHARMACIST.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Yes sir.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The delivery job, I'm interested in it.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: This is for your son?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, for me.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: For you? Well, you have your own car? -

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Gee, I'm sorry, but it's a delivery job. You would need a car.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I have transportation. I own a motor home.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: A motor home?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: I don't really think that would suit this particular job. I have just a few small deliveries a day. Those things aren't too efficient and you probably wouldn't be able to pay for gas with what I'd pay you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, I didn't know I'd have to pay for my own gas.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Yes. Actually, my intention was to get a high school kid with a Rabbit or something. I think an older man with a motor home would be impractical for the both of us. You understand, I don't have that many deliveries. Also, you'd have trouble parking. I don't think this would work out.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I agree.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: You know what I should do? I should cross out "man" and put "boy," "delivery boy" is more correct. I guess "delivery man" is misleading.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, the sign's alright. It looks fine. You don't know of any immensely high-paying jobs in the immediate area, do you?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Um, let me think. No, not in the immediate area.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What about in the outlying areas?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Uh, no. I don't know of any high- paying jobs anywhere in the whole country. Do you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Um, no. Not now. Well, good day.

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Good day to you.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is there an employment agency in  47 this town?

dialogues.speaker: PHARMACIST
dialogues.text: Yes. Just continue down this street about half a mile. It's a small building but you can't miss it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a small employment agency befitting a small town. David is just sitting and waiting his turn along with various other types. David looks a little out of place in that the others look like they want some job relating to alcohol. The AGENT steps out of a small glass cubicle and asks David to step in. David does and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: So. What can we do for you?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I'm originally from Los Angeles and I'm now living here. I need a job.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Alright. He takes out a piece of paper and begins to write down information.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (continuing) What was your previous working experience?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, for the last eight years I was a major executive with one of the biggest advertising agencies in the country.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Oh, I see. And your previous salary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seventy thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: (looks up; he hasn't heard this figure in a long time) You said seventy thousand?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Over how long a period are we talking about?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A year. Seventy thousand a year. The Agent begins to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) What's so funny?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Nothing. That's very good. So, what brings you around these parts? Trying to double up that income? Agent laughs again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. I came here to live. I wanted to change my life.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: You couldn't change your life on seventy thousand?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Could we just get back to what we're doing here?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Sure. Uh, I don't think I have anything at all right now. I mean the only thing I have, you wouldn't be interested in. Why  don't you check back with me in a month?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, you don't know what I'd be interested in. Why don't you just tell me what you have?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: I don't think that coming from your position and your salary you'd be interested in it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, you don't know me. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: It's a crossing guard.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: A crossing guard? You mean at a school?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Yes. Where else do you see them work?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No, I just didn't know if there were different kinds. Well, what does that pay?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: A hundred thousand dollars. He starts to laugh. David laughs along with him.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: But, really, what does it pay?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: It pays three twenty-five an hour, plus benefits.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Benefits meaning what?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Benefits meaning you can get a ride to and from work if you need it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, listen, I've just started looking for work and I don't want to rule anything out but I think I probably can find something where I can use my ability a bit more. Would you have another kind of file, like an executive box or something?

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: What kind of box would that be?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You know, a box of higher-paying jobs.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: My goodness, I forgot. Sure. You mean the hundred thousand dollar box? Agent begins to laugh again.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (getting up) Well, I'm happy I could provide you with your morning's entertainment. You can laugh at me but let me tell you something. I made a statement. You understand what I'm saying? I made a statement.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: A statement?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Never mind. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: AGENT
dialogues.text: Thank you. Good luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is walking dejectedly towards home. Nancy is inside fixing dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters, she turns around excited. She runs up and gives him a hug.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Guess what?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (perking up a bit; at least one of them sounds like they had success) A job?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Sure looks like it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Fantastic! (he sits down) Tell me everything. What is it? How much do you get? When do you start?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I won't know anything for sure until tomorrow. I don't want to say anything until then.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh come on! Tell me? At least tell me what the job is.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Please. We'll get all excited and then what if I don't get it? Let's just wait.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Just give me a hint!

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well... alright. I would be an assistant manager.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Jesus! After one day? Assistant manager! Where?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's all I'm saying. The manager's thinking it over. He said he'll let me know tomorrow. I don't want to jinx it. Now, come on. Let's hear about you. What happened? David can't get over the words "Assistant Manager." His own search hasn't brought him words of that caliber. He hedges.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I'm not saying anything either, but I'll also know in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I gave you a hint, you have to give me one.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I can't. I have too many leads. I've had many firm offers and right now I'm just mulling them over.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What kind of offers?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Listen, I think you're right, we're going to jinx this thing. Let's just keep the mystery. It's more exciting that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is standing with an older MAN in front of a locker. The Man takes out a uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, this won't fit you exactly "cause the fellow who had this before was about eighty and very heavy, but if you go up to the nurse's office they'll take it in.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Now, I don't have the sign here, but do you understand? It's stop on one side...

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Yes. Go on the other.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: No. If you're going to interrupt me I'm not going to be able to explain it. It's stop an one side and stop on the other. It's just a stop sign. So, when you want people to go you'll have to hide the sign.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's right. I remember. You just put it down so people can't see.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: That's right. Behind your back is generally the best place.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Yes. I think, basically, this job hasn't changed since I went to school.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Aren't you a little young for this kind of work?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I don't think so. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, all the other guards here have been in their late sixties or seventies. We had one who was fifty once but that's as young as I can remember.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, times are changing. I mean stereotypes have to be broken sometime, don't they?

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I guess they do. I never thought they did but yeah, I guess they do. Okay. Happy to have you here and I guess all you should know is that some of these children are rude.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, all children are rude.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: Well, these children are a little ruder than they used to be. You see we had this cutback in the school lunch program and sometimes they're hungry. And you know what happens when you're hungry? You get a little bit ornery. I guess what I'm saying is you'll need a little bit of tolerance.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, tolerance is my middle name. Believe me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David is at the crosswalk. He's leading a group of CHILDREN across the street. They are about twelve years old. Obviously, old enough to cross by them- selves. David greets them. He wants to make a good impression. God knows why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, children. How was school?

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Screw you!

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Yeah. Mind your own business.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Ah. You must be two of the hungry ones. The Kids glare at him. David walks back across the street alone. David is waiting. A bunch of KIDS, a little older, about six of them, walk up. One of them says:

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: Hey, who's the new Retardo?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Oh, my goodness. More hungry children. You want to cross the street?

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: Yeah, Retardo.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: My name is David. I would appreciate not being called that name. It's an ugly name.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: Ugly name for an ugly face.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I see no reason to walk future prisoners across the street. Why don't you get some practice working on your own right now since you'll probably be in solitary most of your life. You can handle it.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: No, man. That's what you're paid for. Come on. Take us across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I can't take you across the street and, also, I'm allowed to make judgments. If I think someone shouldn't be allowed to cross the street I'm allowed to deny them that privilege. So, if you want to cross, you'll have to cross on your own.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: Hey, no. No, man. You work for us. Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean let's go? Is that a threat? Be careful. I've got a metal sign here.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER KID
dialogues.text: (takes out a knife) Yeah? I've got a metal knife.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Knife wins. Come on. He leads them across the street. David walks back alone, mumbling. He sits in his little chair. There's no action and no children. Cars are passing by. A new black MERCEDES SCREECHES UP. The passenger window is electrically lowered. A GUY, in his early 30's, calls to David.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Mister?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Call me David. I'm your age. I look a little older because I'm in this uniform.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: David, how do I get out of this place? Actually, what is this place?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What town is this?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Prescott.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. I'm lost. How do I get to Phoenix?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: You have to get on Highway 90. So, what you do is go down about two miles, you'll come to a stoplight, you turn right and keep going and you'll see a sign.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Two miles down and then right?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's it.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hold it. David approaches the car. He sticks his head inside and starts sniffing, rather intensely.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Stop doing that. Get away.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm just smelling the interior. This is leather, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: It's Mercedes Leather. They call it leather but it's vinyl. Smells like leather, though. Huh?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (still sniffing) Yeah it does. You like this car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's not to like? Hey, thanks, man. See ya. He floors it and tears off into the distance. David watches the car slowly disappear. He's still sniffing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to himself) It smelled like leather. They must spray it with something. Interrupting David's thought is a CHILD'S VOICE coming from behind him.

dialogues.speaker: CHILD
dialogues.text: Hey, Retardo! Over here!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (to himself) Without even looking I'm sure he means me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: David enters. Nancy is taking off her coat. David can see that she has on a uniform. It's a candy-striped short skirt and blouse. Also, she has on a candy- striped apron and hat. It looks familiar but David can't quite place it.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hi. Nancy turns around.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: My God! You scared me. They stare at each other, each looking at the other's uniform.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (continuing) You got your job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Did you get yours?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, I did.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Is that a uniform you're wearing?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Of course. What did you think, I bought this?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: What do you do?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I work at Burger King. I got it. I'm the assistant manager.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Burger King?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: The reason I wasn't sure last night was because the manager said he needed time to sleep on it, but this morning he told me he made his decision as soon as I left. He just didn't know how to get hold of me.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Hold it a second. Burger King? The hamburger place? Just after David finishes this sentence, we hear the TOILET FLUSH. Out comes SKIP, a nineteen-year-old boy, dressed in the male version of the same uniform Nancy is wearing. Skip is one of those kids who talks like he's from Torrance, through his nose, blending all syl- lables into one, a kid whose speech could mask his intelligence, if there was intelligence to be masked.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (continuing) Nancy, who's this child?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Oh. This is Skip. He's the manager. He wanted to see where we live. David just stares. His image of the "Manager" was obviously way off. Before

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks, Nancy. Wow, this is like a real home. Now, when you flush the toilet, where does it go? Nancy can answer, Skip sees David.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: (continuing) Oh, wow! Who's the crossing guard?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: That's what you are! A crossing guard! I couldn't place it. That's wonderful! You're working with children!

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I'm walking with children. There's a difference, but we'll talk about it later. Now, tell me again. This child is who?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: This is Skip. He's the manager.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: The manager? This is who slept on it? Skip stretches his hand out eagerly wiping it first on his pants, just to make sure it's clean.

dialogues.speaker: SKIP
dialogues.text: Hey, it's nice to meet you. Call me Skippy, though, huh? That's what my friends call me. Hey, your wife's really something. Man, I think what you're both doing is amazing. She told me all about it. It's really great. You've got a lot of courage. It blew my mind. I'll tell ya, man,  53 when I get old, I sure hope I drop out. It really sounds neat. Hey, did she tell ya what happened today?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (a little embarrassed) David just got home, Skip. I'll tell him later.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. Let Skippy tell it. I want to hear him talk some more.

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Hey, thanks. Well, you know the fry machine? We were never using it right. See, no one ever told us. I mean we did everything the instructions said. You know, we put the oil in and everything, but we took the fries out, like, much too soon and no one knew. And your wife said, "Hey, these are frozen in the middle." And then we took them outside and we looked at 'em in the sun and she was right! They were still frozen. She spotted it on the first day! Do you believe it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: And how long were you making them the other way?

dialogues.speaker: SKIPPY
dialogues.text: Oh, I don't know, a little less than a year.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Nancy, where are the keys?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: They're in the ignition. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are somewhere outside of Prescott. David and Nancy are driving along. They are still in their Burger King and crossing guard outfits, but obviously they have left their first home. Nancy has a map in her hand. She's looking it over.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: You know I think Denver could be a good place to go.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Denver, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Well, it's bigger. We do need a bigger city.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We certainly do. Sweetheart, let's talk for a second.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I love you very much. You know that, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I love you, too.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, I think it's wonderful that we could say this and mean it. Do you know that ever since we were married I just was waiting for us to get divorced? I never thought we would make it, ever. But now I do.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I know. I feel the same way.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, my God, that's wonderful. I mean the experiences that we went through in the last two weeks, it did that. It showed us that we're going to be married forever.  Nancy, we're together for the rest of our lives and I'm so grateful to finally have that peace of mind. It's wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I told you this would all be a blessing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: I know you did. But now, let's talk facts. Our nest egg broke. Forget who did it, no blame. That's not the point. The point is we didn't split up. We stayed together and decided to rebuild. And it was the best decision we ever made. Because for the first time we really know how to share. Whatever we have we can enjoy it together.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: But we don't have anything.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: There! Now we're getting to it. This afternoon I was guiding some children across the street and I realized something. Given our age, and the years we have left together, and the way we're going about this rebuilding program, we will never have another egg in our lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: I was thinking the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Yes. As a matter-of-fact, I began thinking what we might do to speed things up.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: That's amazing. So was I. Denver? Is that what Denver is about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not exactly. I was just kind of thinking of a general plan.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Great. What?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Well, you tell me yours first.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (hesitating) No, you go first.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: No. I'm almost embarrassed to tell you, mine's like a last resort.

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Don't be embarrassed. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: (hesitating) Well...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Come on.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Okay. I thought we'd just get to New York as fast as we can...

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: (interrupts) And you eat shit?

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: Your plan too, huh?

dialogues.speaker: NANCY
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: DAVID
dialogues.text: We really are a team.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We certainly are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It does a fast U-turn away from the northern direction and begins heading east. They are now on their way to New York going as fast as they can. As they do the THEME from the commercial "I LOVE NEW YORK" BEGINS TO PLAY. It grows and grows in intensity as David and Nancy cross the United States. Their trip from Arizona to New York will take place in a space of about thirty seconds. States whiz by. Signs "ENTERING MISSOURI"

dialogues.speaker: "LEAVING MISSOURI" "ENTERING VIRGINIA," "LEAVING
dialogues.text: VIRGINIA," all taking place in a period of seconds. The MUSIC is getting more intense. It's now filling our ears. VOICES BEGIN SINGING, "I LOVE NEW YORK."

dialogues.speaker: SNOW
dialogues.text: We see the mobile home approaching the George Washington Bridge. As it enters the tollbooth we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Monday morning, 8:45. Thousands of New Yorkers are filing into their offices. We see the motor home pull up in front of the advertising agency. Hundreds of people are entering this building. We see that one of these people is Brad Tooley, the baldheaded man David was supposed to work under. From a LONG SHOT, we see David exit the motor home. He's still in his crossing guard uniform. He's been up for three days, taking No Doz and drinking hundreds of cups of coffee. He looks like hell. He runs down the street and corners Brad near the front entrance. Brad sees David. He's scared. He can't believe it. He starts to run. He tries to escape. David turns after him. All this is shown ina LONG SHOT, with the busy Madison Avenue traffic in the foreground. We hear David yelling:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brad, I made it! Three weeks on the button! Let's go to work. We got Fords to sell! Brad looks frightened. He'd like to get away but he can't. David catches up to him. He grabs him around the waist. He drops to his knees. He begins to plead. As New Yorkers pass by going about their business, we see David begging. Brad just staring down at him. OVER THIS SCENE the following CRAWL appears on the screen "Most people lead their entire lives without ever having the courage to break the mold, to find out who they really are and what life is all about. Those that do should take Route 16. This goes through Utah, avoiding the state of Nevada completely."
